title: Goodness of fit
text: ospsuite.plots library provides functions compare predicted observed data resulting residuals: plotPredVsObs() (see section 2): plot predicted values versus corresponding observed values. plotResVsCov() (see section 3): plot residuals points versus covariate (e.g., Time, observed values, Age). plotRatioVsCov() (see section 4): plot ratios points versus covariate (e.g., Time, observed values, Age). plotQQ() (see section 5): Quantile-Quantile plot. functions, aesthetics observed predicted can used. aesthetics also available functions ospsuite.plots library: plotBoxwhisker() (see section 6.1): aggregate residuals display aggregated values versus covariate. plotHistogram() (see section 6.2): generates histograms residuals. functions plotPredVsObs(), plotResVsCov(), plotRatioVsCov() mainly wrappers around function plotXVsY(), using different defaults input variables. , use ?plotXvsY get details. DDI comparison, functions plotPredVsObs() plotResVsObs() can overlaid lines indicating limits Guest Criteria (https://dmd.aspetjournals.org/content/39/2/170) (see section 7).

title: Goodness of fit
text: vignette uses ospsuite.plots tidyr libraries. use default settings ospsuite.plots (see vignette(“ospsuite.plots”, package = “ospsuite.plots”)).
code: library(ospsuite.plots) library(tidyr)  oldDefaults <- setDefaults()

title: Goodness of fit
text: vignette uses two randomly generated example datasets provided package.

what: 1.2.1 Dataset with Predicted and Observed Data
title: Goodness of fit
text: First rows example data. List meta data
code: data <- exampleDataCovariates %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet2") %>%   dplyr::select(c("ID", "Age", "Obs", "gsd", "Pred", "Sex"))  knitr::kable(head(data), digits = 3, caption = "First rows of example data.") metaData <- attr(exampleDataCovariates, "metaData") metaData <- metaData[intersect(names(data), names(metaData))] knitr::kable(metaData2DataFrame(metaData), digits = 2, caption = "List of meta data")

what: 1.2.2 Dataset for Examples with DDI Prediction
title: Goodness of fit
text: First rows dataset used DDI example. List meta data
code: dDIdata <- exampleDataCovariates %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet3") %>%   dplyr::select(c("ID", "Obs", "Pred")) %>%   dplyr::mutate(Study = paste("Study", ID))  dDIdata$Study <- factor(dDIdata$Study, levels = unique(dDIdata$Study))  knitr::kable(head(dDIdata), digits = 2, caption = "First rows of dataset used for DDI example.") dDImetaData <- list(   Obs = list(dimension = "DDI AUC Ratio", unit = ""),   Pred = list(dimension = "DDI AUC Ratio", unit = "") )  knitr::kable(metaData2DataFrame(dDImetaData), digits = 2, caption = "List of meta data")

title: Goodness of fit
code: pkRatioData <- exampleDataCovariates %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet1") %>%   dplyr::select(!c("SetID")) %>%   dplyr::mutate(gsd = 1.1)  pkRatiometaData <- attr(exampleDataCovariates, "metaData") pkRatiometaData <- pkRatiometaData[intersect(names(pkRatioData), names(pkRatiometaData))]  knitr::kable(head(pkRatioData), digits = 3) knitr::kable(metaData2DataFrame(pkRatiometaData), digits = 3)

title: Goodness of fit
text: Basic example using default settings. Predicted observed data mapped predicted observed. aesthetic groupby can used group observations.
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     observed = Obs,     predicted = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData )

title: Goodness of fit
text: scale x y axes set linear. intended use different scales x y axes. Therefore, one variable xyscale exists axes. Predicted observed data mapped x y.
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData,   xyscale = "linear" )

title: Goodness of fit
text: Error bars observed data plotted. example, done mapping error_relative. Error bars also produced mapping error column additive error mapping xmin xmax explicitly.
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     error_relative = gsd,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData )

what: 2.1.4 Error Bars for Observed and Predicted Data
title: Goodness of fit
text: plot prediction error, ymin ymax must also mapped explicitly.
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     error_relative = gsd,     ymin = Pred * 0.9,     ymax = Pred * 1.1,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData )

title: Goodness of fit
text: , dataset created LLOQ set 0.1 quantile observed data. values set LLOQ/2. mapping lloq, data displayed lighter alpha, horizontal line LLOQ added.
code: lloqData <- signif(quantile(data$Obs, probs = 0.1), 1)  dataLLOQ <- data %>%   dplyr::mutate(lloq = lloqData) %>%   dplyr::mutate(Obs = ifelse(Obs <= lloq, lloq / 2, Obs))  plotPredVsObs(   data = dataLLOQ,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     lloq = lloq,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Predicted vs Observed (plotPredVsObs()) > 2.2 Adjust Comparison Lines
title: Goodness of fit
text: plotPredVsObs() adds lines indicate fold distances. lines defined variable comparisonLineVector, named list default values list(identity = 1, '1.5 fold' = c(1.5, 1/1.5), '2 fold' = c(2, 1/2)). fold distance list can generated helper function ?getFoldDistanceList(). , 1.2 1.5 distances displayed:
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData,   comparisonLineVector = getFoldDistanceList(c(1.2, 1.5)) )

previous_headings: 2. Predicted vs Observed (plotPredVsObs()) > 2.2 Adjust Comparison Lines
title: Goodness of fit
text: names list displayed legend. list unnamed, lines displayed line type, included legend. line type used settable variable geomComparisonLineAttributes. variable comparisonLineVector NULL, lines displayed.
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData,   comparisonLineVector = unname(getFoldDistanceList(c(1.2, 1.5))),   geomComparisonLineAttributes = list(linetype = "dotted") )

title: Goodness of fit
text: add regression line, set input variable addRegression TRUE (). regression lines, package ggpubr function stat_regline_equation add statistics regression labels (B). use functions, e.g., local polynomial regression, use ggplot2::geom_smooth directly (C).
code: # A plotObject <- plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData,   addRegression = TRUE ) +   labs(title = "Regression Line", tag = "A")  plot(plotObject) # B plotObject + ggpubr::stat_regline_equation(aes(label = after_stat(rr.label))) + labs(title = "With RR as Label", tag = "B") # C Local Polynomial Regression Fitting plotPredVsObs(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData,   addRegression = FALSE ) +   geom_smooth(method = "loess", formula = "y ~ x", na.rm = TRUE) +   labs(title = "Local Polynomial Regression Fitting", tag = "C")

title: Goodness of fit
text: compare DDI ratios, set variable addGuestLimits TRUE set variable deltaGuest:
code: plotPredVsObs(   data = dDIdata,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Study   ),   metaData = dDImetaData,   addGuestLimits = TRUE,   comparisonLineVector = list(identity = 1),   deltaGuest = 1 )

title: Goodness of fit
text: default, plotPredVsObs() produces square plot aspect ratio 1 limits x y axes. example , Predicted values set 1/2 original values. square plot make sense anymore; therefore, variable asSquarePlot set FALSE.
code: dataNonSquare <- data %>%   dplyr::mutate(Pred = Pred / 2)  plotPredVsObs(   data = dataNonSquare,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     y = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData,   asSquarePlot = FALSE )

title: Goodness of fit
text: function plotResVsCov() calculates residuals using aesthetics observed predicted.

title: Goodness of fit
text: default value variable residualScale “log”. Residuals calculated log(observed) - log(predicted). horizontal comparison line value 0 displayed. aesthetic groupby can used group observations.
code: plotResVsCov(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ) )

title: Goodness of fit
text: variable residualScale set “linear”, residuals calculated #$# observed - predicted #$#. , line type comparison line set ‘solid’.
code: plotResVsCov(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ),   residualScale = "linear",   geomComparisonLineAttributes = list(linetype = "solid") )

title: Goodness of fit
text: also possible use already calculated residuals formulas using aesthetic ‘y’.
code: plotResVsCov(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     y = Obs - Pred,     groupby = Sex   ) )

title: Goodness of fit
code: plotResVsCov(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ),   comparisonLineVector = list(zero = 0, "lower limit" = -0.25, "upper limit" = 0.25) )

title: Goodness of fit
text: add regression line, set input variable addRegression TRUE. regression lines, package ggpubr nice function stat_regline_equation add statistics regression labels.
code: plotResVsCov(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ),   addRegression = TRUE ) +   ggpubr::stat_regline_equation(aes(label = after_stat(eq.label)))

title: Goodness of fit
text: plotRatioVsCov() used evaluate ratios versus covariate. default, identity 1.5 2 point lines added, default yscale ‘log’. aesthetic groupby can used group observations.
code: plotRatioVsCov(   data = pkRatioData,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     y = Ratio,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData )

title: Goodness of fit
text: Within function plotRatioVsCov(), variable residualScale fixed “ratio”, ratio residuals calculated $ observed / predicted $. , comparison line set 1.2 fold distance.
code: plotRatioVsCov(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ),   comparisonLineVector = getFoldDistanceList(c(1.2)) )

what: 4.1.3 Using {ospsuite.plots} Specific Aesthetics like MDV and error_relative
title: Goodness of fit
text: data omitted, can mapping logical column aesthetic mdv. , exclude data Age less 20. Additional error bars displayed mapping column “gsd” aesthetic error_relative.
code: plotRatioVsCov(   data = pkRatioData,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     y = Ratio,     error_relative = gsd,     mdv = Age < 20,     groupby = Sex   ) ) + theme(legend.box = "horizontal", legend.title = element_blank())

title: Goodness of fit
text: data.table package installed variable comparisonLineVector named list, {ggplot} object returned plotRatioVsCov additional entry countsWithin, contains data.frame fractions within specific ranges given variable comparisonLineVector. Counts fraction within ranges
code: plotObject <- plotRatioVsCov(   data = pkRatioData,   mapping = aes(     x = Age,     y = Ratio,     groupby = Sex   ),   metaData = metaData )  plot(plotObject)  knitr::kable(plotObject$countsWithin, caption = "Counts and fraction within ranges")

title: Goodness of fit
text: compare DDI ratios, set variable addGuestLimits TRUE set variable deltaGuest.
code: plotObject <- plotRatioVsCov(   data = dDIdata,   mapping = aes(     x = Obs,     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Study   ),   metaData = dDImetaData,   addGuestLimits = TRUE,   comparisonLineVector = 1 )  print(plotObject) knitr::kable(plotObject$countsWithin)

title: Goodness of fit
text: plotQQ() produces Quantile-Quantile plot. using aesthetics predicted observed, residuals calculated according variable residualScale. example , default value log used.  aesthetic ‘sample’ columns already calculated residuals formulas can mapped directly.
code: plotQQ(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ) ) plotQQ(   data = data,   mapping = aes(     sample = Obs,     predicted = Pred,     groupby = Sex   ),   residualScale = "linear" )

what: 6 Usage of Aesthetics predicted and observed in Other Functions
title: Goodness of fit
text: aesthetics observed predicted can also used functions plotHistogram() plotBoxWhisker(). residuals calculated defined variable residualScale.

previous_headings: 6 Usage of Aesthetics predicted and observed in Other Functions
title: Goodness of fit
code: plotHistogram(   data = data,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     groupby = Sex   ),   residualScale = "log",   plotAsFrequency = TRUE,   distribution = "normal" ) + geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed")

previous_headings: 6 Usage of Aesthetics predicted and observed in Other Functions
what: 6.2 Stratify Residuals with a Box-Whisker Plot
title: Goodness of fit
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     predicted = Pred,     observed = Obs,     x = Sex   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   residualScale = "linear" )

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: vignette documents illustrates workflows producing box--whisker plots using ospsuite.plots library. function plotting box-whiskers plotBoxWhisker. Basic documentation function can found using: ?plotBoxWhisker. output function ggplot object.

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: vignette uses ospsuite.plots tidyr libraries. use default settings ospsuite.plots (see vignette(“ospsuite.plots”, package = “ospsuite.plots”)) adjust legend position alignment caption.
code: library(ospsuite.plots) library(tidyr)  # Set Defaults oldDefaults <- ospsuite.plots::setDefaults()  # Adjust default theme plot for prettier plots theme_update(legend.position = "top") theme_update(legend.direction = "horizontal") theme_update(plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 1))

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: vignette uses dataset provided package: First rows example data pkRatioData Metadata list contains dimension unit information dataset columns. available, axis labels set information. List meta data
code: pkRatioData <- exampleDataCovariates %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet1") %>%   dplyr::select(-c("SetID", "gsd", "AgeBin")) %>%   dplyr::mutate(Agegroup = cut(Age, breaks = c(0, 6, 12, 18, 60), include.lowest = TRUE, labels = c("infants", "school children", "adolescents", "adults")))  knitr::kable(head(pkRatioData), digits = 3, caption = "First rows of example data pkRatioData") metaData <- attr(exampleDataCovariates, "metaData") knitr::kable(metaData2DataFrame(metaData), digits = 2, caption = "List of meta data")

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.1 Examples for Aggregation of Categorical Data
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: Age (mapped y) aggregated.
code: plotBoxWhisker(data = pkRatioData, mapping = aes(y = Age), metaData = metaData)

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.1 Examples for Aggregation of Categorical Data
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: Age (mapped y) aggregated different countries (mapped x).
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.1 Examples for Aggregation of Categorical Data
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: Age (mapped y) aggregated different countries (mapped fill).
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     fill = Country,     y = Age   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.1 Examples for Aggregation of Categorical Data
what: 2.1.4 Stratification by Color and on X-axis
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: Age (mapped y) aggregated different countries (mapped x) Sex (mapped groupby). groupby additional aesthetic ospsuite.plots works together variable groupAesthetics. function plotBoxWhisker(), groupAesthetics settable fixed fill.
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age,     groupby = Sex   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.1 Examples for Aggregation of Categorical Data

text: , groupby mapped combination columns “Sex” “Country”:
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     y = Age,     groupby = interaction(Country, Sex, sep = "-")   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData ) + theme(legend.title = element_blank())

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.1 Examples for Aggregation of Categorical Data
what: 2.1.6 Omit Data Points Flagged as Missing Dependent Variable (MDV)
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: data omitted, can mapping logical column aesthetic mdv. , exclude data Germany:
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age,     mdv = Country == "Germany",     groupby = Sex   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.2 Examples for Box-Whisker vs Numeric Data
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: next example, added numeric column “mean age” age group dataset. column mapped factor x. values now displayed categorical values equidistant:
code: pkRatioData <- pkRatioData %>%   dplyr::group_by(Agegroup) %>%   dplyr::mutate(meanAge = round(mean(Age), 2))  metaData[["meanAge"]] <- metaData[["Age"]] metaData <- metaData[intersect(names(pkRatioData), names(metaData))]  plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   mapping = aes(     x = as.factor(meanAge),     y = Ratio,     fill = Agegroup   ),   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.2 Examples for Box-Whisker vs Numeric Data
what: 2.2.2 Numeric Data as Distinct Numeric Values
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: column mapped x numeric factor, x-position boxes corresponds numeric value:
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = meanAge,     y = Ratio,     fill = Agegroup   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData )

previous_headings: 2. Examples > 2.2 Examples for Box-Whisker vs Numeric Data
title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: mapping x function, possible aggregate data continuous column bins. , use function cut aggregate data 4 distinct bins (see ?cut). Attention: cut(Age), metaData exists. set x label manually.  can use function converts continuous vector factor. , define cut function simply wrapper around cut, fixed arguments. function mapped x groupby.
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = cut(Age, 4),     y = Ratio   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData ) + labs(x = "Age range [years]") myCutfun <- function(x) {   cut(x = x, breaks = c(0, 6, 12, 18, 60), include.lowest = TRUE, labels = c("infants", "school children", "adolescents", "adults")) }  plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = myCutfun(Age),     y = Ratio,     groupby = myCutfun(Age)   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData ) +   theme(legend.title = element_blank()) +   labs(x = "")

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: default, data aggregated percentiles defined default option ospsuite.plots.Percentiles. percentiles can customized specific plot input variable percentiles plots generated plotBoxWhisker() changing default options (setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$Percentiles, value = c(0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.95))). also possible use customized function via input variable statFun. statFun NULL, overwrite percentiles. Important: override defaults way, please make sure specify plot annotations, essentially redefining box plot, reader might misinterpret .

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: example , show whiskers setting whisker percentiles box percentiles.
code: # B No whiskers plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   percentiles = c(0.25, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.75) )

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: customize aggregation, provide function input vector aggregate output named list entries ymin, lower, middle, upper, ymax. example , function myStatFun provided, uses mean standard deviation aggregate:
code: myStatFun <- function(y) {   r <- list(     ymin = mean(y) - 1.96 * stats::sd(y),     lower = mean(y) - stats::sd(y),     middle = mean(y),     upper = mean(y) + stats::sd(y),     ymax = mean(y) + 1.96 * stats::sd(y)   )   return(r) }  plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   statFun = myStatFun ) + labs(caption = "Mean for the middle line, mean +/- standard deviation for the box edges, and mean +/- 1.96 standard deviation for the whiskers.")

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: already exist many possibilities aggregate data R, package provide extra function return aggregated data tabular form. However, plotBoxWhisker() adds aggregation function plot object. aggregation can easily done, e.g., data.table package using function used plot.
code: # Generate plot object plotObject <- plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age,     fill = Sex   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData )  plot(plotObject)  # Convert data to data.table and use statFun saved in plotObject for aggregation # Make sure to add all relevant aesthetics to "by" columns dt <- plotObject$data %>%   data.table::setDT() %>%   .[, as.list(plotObject$statFun(Age)), by = c("Country", "Sex")]  knitr::kable(dt)

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: Outliers displayed variable outliers TRUE. Default outliers flagged outside range “25th” percentile - 1.5 x IQR “75th” percentile + 1.5 x IQR.
code: plotBoxWhisker(   mapping = aes(     x = Sex,     y = Ratio,     fill = Country   ),   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   outliers = TRUE ) + labs(tag = "A", caption = "Default settings: Whiskers indicate 90% range (5th - 95th percentile) and outliers indicate all measurements outside 25th percentiles - 1.5 x IQR to 75th percentiles + 1.5 x IQR.")

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: following example, aggregation customized set whiskers 10% 90% via input variable percentiles, outlier range customized show points outside whiskers. , define function myStatFunOutlier, input vector values output vector values outside outlier range.
code: myStatFunOutlier <- function(y) {   q <- stats::quantile(y, probs = c(0.1, 0.9), names = FALSE, na.rm = TRUE)   yOutsideRange <- subset(y, y < q[1] | y > q[2])    if (length(yOutsideRange) < 1) {     return(as.double(NA))   } else {     return(yOutsideRange)   } }  plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = Sex,     y = Ratio,     fill = Country   ),   outliers = TRUE,   percentiles = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9),   statFunOutlier = myStatFunOutlier ) + labs(caption = "Whiskers indicate 80% range (10th - 90th percentile) and outliers indicate all measurements outside whiskers.")

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: plotBoxWhisker() adds outlier function plot object. outliers can easily retrieved, e.g., data.table package.
code: # Generate plotObject plotObject <- plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = Sex,     y = Ratio,     fill = Country   ),   outliers = TRUE,   percentiles = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9),   statFunOutlier = myStatFunOutlier )  # Convert data to data.table and use statFun saved in plotObject for aggregation # Make sure to add all relevant aesthetics to "by" columns dt <- plotObject$data %>%   data.table::setDT() %>%   .[, .(outliers = plotObject$statFunOutlier(Ratio)), by = c("Country", "Sex")]  knitr::kable(dt)

title: Box-Whisker Plots
text: see example plot: default layout B customized layout variable geomBoxplotAttributes now entry color ‘orange’. variable geomPointAttributes now entry size = 4, color ‘orange’, shape = ‘diamond’. Fill added mapping, outlier points also colored according ‘Sex’. scale_fill_manual, colors ‘Sex’ defined.
code: # A default layout plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age,     fill = Sex   ),   outliers = TRUE,   percentiles = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9),   statFunOutlier = myStatFunOutlier ) + labs(tag = "A")  # B customized layout plotBoxWhisker(   data = pkRatioData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = Country,     y = Age,     fill = Sex   ),   outliers = TRUE,   percentiles = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9),   statFunOutlier = myStatFunOutlier,   geomBoxplotAttributes = list(color = "orange", position = position_dodge(width = 1)),   geomPointAttributes = list(position = position_dodge(width = 1), size = 4, color = "orange", shape = "diamond") ) + scale_fill_manual(values = c(Female = "pink", Male = "dodgerblue")) + labs(tag = "B")

title: Histogram Plots
text: vignette documents illustrates workflows producing histograms using function plotHistogram ospsuite.plots package.

title: Histogram Plots
text: vignette uses ospsuite.plots tidyr libraries. use default settings ospsuite.plots (see vignette(“ospsuite.plots”, package = “ospsuite.plots”)) adjust legend position.
code: library(ospsuite.plots) #> Loading required package: ggplot2 library(tidyr)  # Set Defaults oldDefaults <- ospsuite.plots::setDefaults()  # Place default legend position above the plot for clearer histogram plots theme_update(legend.position = "top") theme_update(legend.direction = "horizontal") theme_update(legend.title = element_blank())

title: Histogram Plots
text: vignette uses following datasets: Data Set 1: First rows example data. List meta data Data Set 2: First rows distribution data. List meta data distribution data
code: histData <- exampleDataCovariates %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet1") %>%   dplyr::select(c("ID", "Sex", "Age", "AgeBin", "Ratio"))  # Metadata metaData <- attr(exampleDataCovariates, "metaData") metaData <- metaData[intersect(names(histData), names(metaData))]  knitr::kable(head(histData), digits = 2, caption = "First rows of example data.") knitr::kable(metaData2DataFrame(metaData), digits = 2, caption = "List of meta data") histDataDistr <- exampleDataCovariates %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet2") %>%   dplyr::select(c("ID", "AgeBin", "Sex", "Obs"))  # Metadata for Distribution Data metaDataDistr <- attr(exampleDataCovariates, "metaData") metaDataDistr <- metaDataDistr[intersect(names(histDataDistr), names(metaDataDistr))]  knitr::kable(head(histDataDistr), digits = 2, caption = "First rows of distribution data.") knitr::kable(metaData2DataFrame(metaDataDistr), digits = 2, caption = "List of meta data for distribution data")

title: Histogram Plots
text: Histogram “Ratio” column mapped x, stratified “Sex” column mapped fill.
code: plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, fill = Sex),   metaData = metaData )

title: Histogram Plots
text: variable geomHistAttributes set default getDefaultGeomAttributes("Hist"), list entries bins = 10 position = ggplot2::position_nudge(). example , variable geomHistAttributes set list entry position = "dodge". changes position, note default value geomHistAttributes contains entry bins = 10, now overwritten, default {ggplot} number 30 used.
code: plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, groupby = Sex),   metaData = metaData,   geomHistAttributes = list(position = "dodge") )

title: Histogram Plots
text: Use input variable geomHistAttributes change binning. entries list passed ggplot2::geom_histogram, provides many possibilities customize binning. , define bin boundaries adding entry breaks geomHistAttributes.  also map binning function aesthetic x. , ggplot2::cut_number used create 3 bins equal numbers observations. data now displayed categorical data.
code: plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, fill = Sex),   geomHistAttributes = list(position = position_nudge(), breaks = seq(0, 5, 0.5)),   metaData = metaData ) plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = cut_number(Ratio, n = 3, labels = c("low", "mean", "high")), fill = Sex),   geomHistAttributes = list(position = position_nudge()),   metaData = metaData ) + labs(x = "Ratio")

title: Histogram Plots
text: variable plotAsFrequency set TRUE : position stack: frequency calculated count per bin / total () position stack: frequency calculated count per bin / per group (B)  plots also calculated directly setting y mapping: position stack: frequency calculated count per bin / total (C) position stack: frequency calculated count per bin / per group (D)
code: # A plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, groupby = Sex),   metaData = metaData,   plotAsFrequency = TRUE,   geomHistAttributes = list(bins = 10, position = "stack") ) + labs(tag = "A", caption = "Frequency is calculated as count per bin / total")  # B plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, groupby = Sex),   metaData = metaData,   plotAsFrequency = TRUE ) + labs(tag = "B", caption = "Frequency is calculated as count per bin / per group") # C plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, fill = Sex, y = after_stat(count / sum(count))),   metaData = metaData,   plotAsFrequency = FALSE,   geomHistAttributes = list(bins = 10, position = "stack") ) + labs(tag = "C", caption = "Frequency is calculated as count per bin / total")  # D plotHistogram(   data = histData,   mapping = aes(x = Ratio, fill = Sex, y = after_stat(density)),   metaData = metaData,   plotAsFrequency = FALSE ) + labs(tag = "D", caption = "Frequency is calculated as count per bin / per group")

title: Histogram Plots
text: optional input variable distribution provides possibility fitting data distribution. distributions package {stats} available (see ?stats::distributions). Internally, ggh4x::stat_theodensity used fit. Check help details. common distributions, keys “normal” (instead norm) “lognormal” (instead lnorm) also accepted. vertical line indicates mean. function calculate mean determined input variable meanFunction. Available options : none (line plotted) mean (arithmetic mean) geomean (geometric mean) median auto (default, selects mean function according selected distribution) examples :

text: function plotHistogram can also used plot categorical data bar plot. Internally, function switches geom_histogram geom_bar. default inputs, function switches automatically bar plot data factor non-numeric. (See plot ). can also done manually setting variable asBarPlot TRUE (see plot B).  ```

text: Functions set ospsuite.plots default theme setDefaultTheme() resetDefaultTheme(). functions called setDefaults() resetDefaults().

title: Overview
text: Functions set ospsuite.plots default color setDefaultColorMapDistinct() resetDefaultColorMapDistinct(). functions called setDefaults() resetDefaults(). Colors set discrete ordinal scales fill colour. package provides color palettes object colorMaps (see ?colorMaps). example shows plots : plot default settings 6 different colors B plot default settings 6 different colors C customized settings following plots using colorMaps[["grays"]] D customized plot: set gray scale plot using function scale_fill_grey() E customized settings following plots using ggsci::pal_lancet()(9) F customized plots: set gray scale plot using function ggsci::scale_color_lancet()
code: # Set ospsuite.plots Default Color oldColors <- ospsuite.plots::setDefaultColorMapDistinct()  ggplot() +   geom_tile(aes(x = rep(seq(1, 3), 2), y = rep(seq(1, 2), each = 3), fill = as.factor(seq(1, 6)))) +   labs(title = "Default settings for up to 6 different colors", tag = "A") +   theme(legend.position = "none", axis.title = element_blank()) ggplot() +   geom_tile(aes(x = c(rep(seq(1, 7), 7), 1, 2), y = c(rep(seq(1, 7), each = 7), 8, 8), fill = as.factor(seq(1, 51)))) +   labs(title = "Default settings for more than 6 different colors") +   theme(legend.position = "none", axis.title = element_blank()) # Customize colors: set to gray colors ospsuite.plots::setDefaultColorMapDistinct(colorMaps[["grays"]])  ggplot() +   geom_tile(aes(x = rep(seq(1, 3), 3), y = rep(seq(1, 3), each = 3), fill = as.factor(seq(1, 9)))) +   theme(legend.position = "none", axis.title = element_blank()) +   labs(title = "colorMaps gray", tag = "C") ggplot() +   geom_tile(aes(x = rep(seq(1, 3), 3), y = rep(seq(1, 3), each = 3), fill = as.factor(seq(1, 9)))) +   theme(legend.position = "none", axis.title = element_blank()) +   scale_fill_grey() +   labs(title = "scale_fill_grey", tag = "D") # Set to color palettes inspired by plots in Lancet journals ospsuite.plots::setDefaultColorMapDistinct(ggsci::pal_lancet()(9))  ggplot() +   geom_tile(aes(x = rep(seq(1, 3), 3), y = rep(seq(1, 3), each = 3), fill = as.factor(seq(1, 9)))) +   theme(legend.position = "none", axis.title = element_blank()) +   labs(title = "ggsci::pal_lancet", tag = "E") # Set to color palettes inspired by plots in Lancet journals ospsuite.plots::setDefaultColorMapDistinct(ggsci::pal_lancet()(9))  ggplot() +   geom_tile(aes(x = rep(seq(1, 3), 3), y = rep(seq(1, 3), each = 3), fill = as.factor(seq(1, 9)))) +   theme(legend.position = "none", axis.title = element_blank()) +   ggsci::scale_color_lancet() +   labs(title = "ggsci::scale_color_lancet", tag = "F")

title: Overview
text: plots packages created function ggplotWithWatermark() instead ggplot(). function creates normal ggplot object printed, watermark added. Attention! combine plots e.g. cowplot:plot_grid default print function without watermark called. case add watermark function addwatermark(plotObject) print. watermark can customized options: Switch watermark (option key = watermark_enabled, default = TRUE) Select label (option key = watermark_label, default = “preliminary analysis”) Customize format (option key = watermark_format, default = list(x = 0.5, y = 0.5, color = "grey20", angle = 30, fontsize = 12, alpha = 0.7))

code: # Change format and label of watermark setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format, value = list(x = 0.2, y = 0.6, color = "red", angle = 90, fontsize = 24, alpha = 0.2)) setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_label, value = "NEW")  # Initialize plot ggplotWithWatermark() + labs(title = "Changed Watermark", tag = "A") # Disable watermark setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_enabled, value = FALSE)  # Initialize plot ggplotWithWatermark() + labs(title = "No Watermark", tag = "B") # Reset to default setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format, value = NULL) setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_label, value = NULL) setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_enabled, value = NULL)  # Initialize plot ggplotWithWatermark() + labs(title = "Default Watermark", tag = "C")

title: Overview
text: package provides additional aesthetics. details, see examples within vignettes respective functions. groupby: Shortcut use different aesthetics group. functions aesthetic used also variable groupAesthetics. mapping groupby copied aesthetics listed within variable aesthetic group. lloq: Mapped column values indicating lower limit quantification, adds horizontal (vertical) lines plot. observed values “lloq” plotted lighter alpha. values compared row row, possible one LLOQ. error: Mapped column additive error (e.g., standard deviation); error bars plotted. shortcut map ymin ymax directly (ymin = y - error ymax = y + error). Additionally, yscale set, ymin values 0 set y. error_relative: Mapped column relative error (e.g., geometric standard deviation); error bars plotted. shortcut map ymin ymax directly (ymin = y / error_relative ymax = y * error_relative). y2axis: Creates plot 2 y axes. used map column logical value. Values column TRUE entry displayed secondary axis. mdv: Mapped logical column. Rows column entries set TRUE plotted (MDV = missing data value, taken NONMEM notation). residualScale = "log": log(observed)−log(predicted)log(observed) - log(predicted), residualScale = "linear": observed−predictedobserved - predicted, residualScale = "ratio": observed/predictedobserved / predicted. See vignette("Goodness Fit", package = "ospsuite.plots") examples. Applicability additional aesthetics functions

title: Overview
code: shapeNames <- c("circle", paste("circle", c("open", "filled", "cross", "plus", "small")), "bullet", "square", paste("square", c("open", "filled", "cross", "plus", "triangle")), "diamond", paste("diamond", c("open", "filled", "plus")), "triangle", paste("triangle", c("open", "filled", "square")), paste("triangle down", c("open", "filled")), "plus", "cross", "asterisk")  shapes <- data.frame(shapeNames = shapeNames, x = c(1:7, 1:6, 1:3, 5, 1:3, 6, 2:3, 1:3), y = -rep(1:6, c(7, 6, 4, 4, 2, 3)))  ggplot(shapes, aes(x, y)) +   geom_point(aes(shape = shapeNames), color = "blue", fill = "red", size = 5, stroke = 1) +   geom_text(aes(label = shapeNames), nudge_y = -0.3, size = 3.5) +   scale_shape_identity() +   theme_void()

title: Overview

code: shapes <- data.frame(shapeNames = names(Shapes), shape_symbols = unlist(unname(Shapes)), x = rep(c(1:5), 8), y = rep(-c(1:8), each = 5))  showtext::showtext_auto() ggplot(shapes, aes(x, y)) +   geomPointUnicode(aes(shape = shape_symbols), color = "blue", fill = "red", size = 5) +   geom_text(aes(label = shapeNames), nudge_y = -0.3, size = 3.5) +   scale_shape_identity() +   theme_void() showtext::showtext_auto(enable = "off")

title: Time Profile Plots
text: vignette documents illustrates workflows producing Time Profile plots using ospsuite.plots library. Time profile plots commonly used compare observed simulated data time. plots, observed data typically represented scatter points error bars indicating population range confidence intervals, simulated data displayed using lines shaded ribbons representing population range confidence intervals. Basic documentation function can found using: ?plotTimeProfile. output function ggplot object.

title: Time Profile Plots
text: vignette uses ospsuite.plots tidyr libraries. use default settings ospsuite.plots (see vignette(“ospsuite.plots”, package = “ospsuite.plots”)) adjust legend position.
code: library(ospsuite.plots) library(tidyr)  # Set Defaults oldDefaults <- ospsuite.plots::setDefaults()  # Adjust legend position for better aesthetics theme_update(legend.position = "top") theme_update(legend.direction = "vertical") theme_update(legend.box = "horizontal") theme_update(legend.title = element_blank())

simData <- rbind(simData1, simData2)  obsData1 <- exampleDataTimeProfile %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet1") %>%   dplyr::filter(Type == "observed") %>%   dplyr::select(c("time", "values", "sd", "maxValues", "minValues", "caption"))  obsData2 <- exampleDataTimeProfile %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet2") %>%   dplyr::filter(Type == "observed") %>%   dplyr::select(c("time", "values", "sd", exampleDataTimeProfile %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == c("DataSet3")) %>%   dplyr::filter(Type == "simulated") %>%   dplyr::filter(dimension == "concentration") %>%   dplyr::select(c("time", "values", "caption"))  obsDataLloq <- exampleDataTimeProfile %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet3") %>%   dplyr::filter(Type == "observed") %>%   dplyr::filter(dimension == "concentration") %>% %>%   dplyr::select(c("time", "values", "dimension", "caption"))  obsData2Dimension <- exampleDataTimeProfile %>%   dplyr::filter(SetID == "DataSet3") %>%   dplyr::filter(Type == "observed") %>% title: Time Profile Plots
text: example, plot generated concentration left y-axis fraction right y-axis. First, metaData variable adjusted. primary y-axis, column “values” mapped, metaData provides dimension “Concentration” column. new entry “y2” added secondary y-axis. mapping y2axis must logical. example, (dimension == "fraction"). primary y-axis (concentration), log scale displayed, secondary (fraction), linear scale used. limits secondary axis set [0, 1].
code: metaDataY2 <- list(   time = list(dimension = "Time", unit = "h"),   values = list(dimension = "Concentration", unit = "mg/l"),   y2 = list(dimension = "Fraction", unit = "") ) plotTimeProfile(   data = simData2Dimension,   observedData = obsData2Dimension,   mapping = aes(     x = time,     y = values,     error_relative = error_relative,     lloq = lloq,     y2axis = (dimension == "fraction"),     groupby = dimension,     shape = caption   ),   metaData = metaDataY2,   yscale = "log",   yscale.args = list(limits = c(0.01, NA)),   y2scale = "linear",   y2scale.args = list(limits = c(0, 1)) ) +   theme(     axis.title.y.right = element_text(angle = 90),     legend.position = "right",     legend.box = "vertical"   )

title: Time Profile Plots
text: plot section 2.3.2 adjusted using geom attributes: geomLineAttributes = list(linetype = 'solid'): lines used simulated data set solid datasets. Note line type error bars ribbon edges remains unchanged. geomErrorbarAttributes = list(): default settings geomErrorbarAttributes, width = 0, removed bar caps now visible. geomRibbonAttributes = list(alpha = 0.1): shade ribbons decreased setting alpha 0.1; default value color = NA omitted, making edges visible. geomPointAttributes = list(size = 7): size symbols increased.
code: mapSimulatedAndObserved <- data.frame(   simulated = unique(simData$caption),   observed = rev(unique(obsData$caption)) )  plotTimeProfile(   data = simData,   observedData = obsData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = time,     y = values,     ymin = minValues,     ymax = maxValues,     groupby = caption   ),   geomLineAttributes = list(linetype = "solid"),   geomErrorbarAttributes = list(width = 3),   geomRibbonAttributes = list(alpha = 0.1),   geomPointAttributes = list(size = 7),   mapSimulatedAndObserved = mapSimulatedAndObserved )

title: Time Profile Plots

code: # Create datasets with common caption simData <- data.frame(simData) %>%   dplyr::mutate(captionCommon = gsub("Simulated ", "", caption))  obsData <- data.frame(obsData) %>%   dplyr::mutate(captionCommon = gsub("Observed ", "", caption))  plotTimeProfile(   data = simData,   observedData = obsData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = time,     y = values,     ymin = minValues,     ymax = maxValues,     groupby = captionCommon   ) ) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Data 1" = "darkred", "Data 2" = "darkgreen")) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Data 1" = "red", "Data 2" = "green"))

previous_headings: 3. Plot Configuration > 3.2 Example for Changing Color Scales
title: Time Profile Plots
text: possible add columns aesthetics table used map simulated observed data. column headers must correspond one aesthetics defined groupAesthetics. example , done ‘color’ ‘fill’:  Changing scales using observed simulation mapping table can also done adding scales manually, bit complicated. mapSimulatedAndObserved null, reset relevant scales done plotting observed data. scales simulated data must set reset. call plotTimeProfile two times: Call plotTimeProfile() simulated data . Set scales simulated data. Call plotTimeProfile() observed data simulated plot input plotObject. Set scales observed data.
code: # Define Data Mappings mapSimulatedAndObserved <- data.frame(   simulated = unique(simData$caption),   observed = unique(obsData$caption),   color = c("darkred", "darkgreen"),   fill = c("red", "green") )  knitr::kable(mapSimulatedAndObserved) plotTimeProfile(   data = simData,   observedData = obsData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = time,     y = values,     ymin = minValues,     ymax = maxValues,     groupby = caption   ),   mapSimulatedAndObserved = mapSimulatedAndObserved ) mapSimulatedAndObserved <- data.frame(   simulated = unique(simData$caption),   observed = rev(unique(obsData$caption)) )  # Define Data Mappings mapping <- aes(   x = time,   y = values,   ymin = minValues,   ymax = maxValues,   groupby = caption )  plotObject <- plotTimeProfile(   data = simData,   metaData = metaData,   mapping = mapping,   mapSimulatedAndObserved = mapSimulatedAndObserved ) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Simulated Data 1" = "darkred", "Simulated Data 2" = "darkgreen")) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("Simulated Data 1" = "red", "Simulated Data 2" = "green"))  plotObject <- plotTimeProfile(   plotObject = plotObject,   observedData = obsData,   mapping = mapping,   mapSimulatedAndObserved = mapSimulatedAndObserved ) +   scale_color_manual(values = c("Observed Data 1" = "darkred", "Observed Data 2" = "darkgreen")) #> Scale for x is already present. #> Adding another scale for x, which will replace the existing scale. #> Scale for y is already present. #> Adding another scale for y, which will replace the existing scale.  plot(plotObject)

title: Time Profile Plots
text: example, set scale y-axis log scale. default, time profile plot starts 0; , defaults overwritten, breaks set manually.
code: plotTimeProfile(   data = simData %>% dplyr::filter(values > 0),   metaData = metaData,   mapping = aes(     x = time + 24,     y = values,     groupby = caption   ),   yscale = "log",   xscale.args = list(limits = c(24, 48), breaks = seq(24, 48, 3)) )

title: Time Profile Plots

code: plotlist <- list()  for (unit in c("h", "day(s)", "weeks(s)", "month(s)")) {   metaData$time$unit <- unit   plotlist[[unit]] <- plotTimeProfile(     data = simData,     metaData = metaData,     mapping = aes(       x = time,       y = values,       groupby = caption     )   ) + labs(title = paste("Time unit:", unit)) + theme(legend.position = "none") }  cowplot::plot_grid(plotlist = plotlist, labels = "AUTO")

what: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: file modified pull request, GitHub Copilot generate Markdown section following structure:

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Copilot must analyze every function every R6 class method file following criteria:

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Code free parse errors. Uses vectorized operations possible. Avoids unnecessary loops. Employs efficient data structures.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Functions classes roxygen2 docstrings. Inline comments present complex/nontrivial logic. Parameters return values described. Explanations meaningful non-obvious logic commented.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Cyclomatic complexity function/method exceed 10. Flag report functions/methods exceeding threshold.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Follows OSP coding standards: https://dev.open-systems-pharmacology.org/r-development-resources/coding_standards_r Naming conventions, indentation, modularity, function length, avoidance hard-coded values, language construct use. Variable function names: lowercase letters/numbers, camelCase. Class names: PascalCase. Constant variables: ALL_CAPS.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: incomplete statements, unmatched parentheses/brackets, unfinished/misleading comments.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Function variable names self-explanatory meaningful. Follows OSP naming conventions (see d).

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: use deprecated discouraged functions, packages, coding patterns.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Proper error/warning handling: use stop(), warning(), tryCatch() appropriate. Error messages informative.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: input arguments validated (e.g., stopifnot(), assertthat, checkmate).

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: obvious duplication; repeated logic refactored helpers.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: unexplained constants “magic numbers”; values named documented.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Return values documented types clear expected.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: Major functions/methods unit tests testable @examples roxygen2 tags. Flag absence missing.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: criterion , create Markdown subsection. Within subsection, provide table findings functions/methods issues. table following columns: last column (Suggestions) provide specific, actionable guidance resolve issue. findings present criterion, omit table criterion.

title: GitHub Copilot Code Review Instructions for R Package PRs
text: criteria (d) (f), always cross-check OSP coding standards: https://dev.open-systems-pharmacology.org/r-development-resources/coding_standards_r Always format output Markdown tables, grouped respective heading. include tables criteria issues found. function method multiple findings (across different criteria), report relevant tables criterion.

title: Add a watermark to a ggplot object — addWatermark
code: # Example usage p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point() p_with_watermark <- addWatermark(p) print(p_with_watermark)   # Example of customizing the watermark setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_label, value = "Custom Watermark") watermark_format <- getOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format) watermark_format$x <- 0.5 # Centered horizontally watermark_format$y <- 0.5 # Centered vertically watermark_format$angle <- 45 # Rotated 45 degrees watermark_format$fontsize <- 6 # Font size 6 watermark_format$color <- "blue" # Blue color watermark_format$alpha <- 0.5 # 50% transparency setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format, value = watermark_format)  # Create plot with customized watermark p_custom <- addWatermark(p) print(p_custom)

title: Create a ggplot with an optional watermark — ggplotWithWatermark

title: Create a ggplot with an optional watermark — ggplotWithWatermark
text: watermark feature enabled, resulting ggplot object include watermark overlay printed. watermark's properties determined options set Ospsuite plotting configuration. following options can used customize watermark: watermark_label: Text displayed watermark. watermark_format: list following entries: x: x-coordinate watermark's position plot. y: y-coordinate watermark's position plot. angle: angle watermark text displayed (degrees). fontsize: size font watermark text. color: color watermark text, specified valid color format (e.g., "red", "#FF0000"). alpha: transparency level watermark text, ranging 0 (completely transparent) 1 (completely opaque).

title: Create a ggplot with an optional watermark — ggplotWithWatermark
code: # Example usage with watermark enabled plotWithWatermark <- ggplotWithWatermark(data = mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point() print(plotWithWatermark)   # Example usage with watermark disabled setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_enabled, value = FALSE) plotWithoutWatermark <- ggplotWithWatermark(data = mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point() print(plotWithoutWatermark)  # Reset options setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_enabled, value = TRUE)  # Example usage with customized watermark setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_label, value = "Custom Label") watermark_format <- getOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format) watermark_format$color <- "red" setOspsuite.plots.option(optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format, value = watermark_format) plotWithCustomizedWatermark <- ggplotWithWatermark(data = mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) +   geom_point() print(plotWithCustomizedWatermark)  # Reset options setOspsuite.plots.option(   optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_format,   value = getDefaultOptions()[[OptionKeys$watermark_format]] ) setOspsuite.plots.option(   optionKey = OptionKeys$watermark_label,   value = getDefaultOptions()[[OptionKeys$watermark_label]] )

title: Generate Box-Whisker Plots — plotBoxWhisker
text: data data.frame containing data aggregate. mapping list aesthetic mappings use plot. metaData named list information data dimension unit variables. plotObject optional ggplot object add plot layers percentiles numeric vector percentiles used box whiskers boxes, e.g., c(0.05, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.95). Default defined ospsuite.plots option. yscale either 'linear' ggplot2::scale_y_continuous() 'log' ggplot2::scale_y_log10() used yscale.args list arguments passed ggplot2::scale_y_continuous() ggplot2::scale_y_log10() xscale Either 'linear', 'log', 'discrete', 'auto' (default). Auto selects linear continuous data discrete categorical data. xscale.args list arguments passed ggplot2::scale_x_continuous(), ggplot2::scale_x_log10(), ggplot2::scale_x_discrete(). statFun (default NULL) function calculate whiskers box ranges, overwrites percentiles variable provided. outliers Logical indicating whether outliers included boxplot. Outliers flagged outside range "25th" percentile - 1.5 x IQR "75th" percentile + 1.5 x IQR, suggested McGill et al. statFunOutlier (default NULL) function calculate outliers, overwrites default calculation provided. geomBoxplotAttributes list arguments passed geom_boxplot call. geomPointAttributes list arguments passed ggplot2::geom_point call. residualScale Either "linear", "log", "ratio" scale residuals.

Specifically, continue double width finds width suitable, ensuring 10 times width still less total range time values. means breaks spaced far enough apart meaningful without overcrowding axis, providing clarity visualization.
